segments.text: Test 1, 2, 3.
This is an interview with Colonel Barbé by Christian Williams on 29 April 1993 at the Trigon concerning Colonel Barbé's experiences in Vietnam.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I am asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you, sir?
Sure is.
Please state your name, sir.
Yeah, my name's William Leland Barbay.
You're in current position to hold the university, sir?
I'm the professor of naval science and the CO of the NROTC unit.
Your date of birth, sir, and place of birth?
I was born in Kinston, North Carolina on 4 April, 1942.
Sir, if you could briefly tell me a little bit about your parents, their careers, and your family life.
Well, I'm a Marine junior.
My dad was a career Marine, was in the Marine Corps for 27 years and fought in both the World War II and the Korean conflict.
I can follow it up to say I kind of lived all over the United States and overseas as a child.
I mean, as my dad traveled quite a bit, being in the military.
So what motivated you to become a Marine officer?
Well, I've always been a very patriotic person.
I kind of grew up in the Marine Corps.
I was used to kind of the Marine Corps way of life.
I love to travel.
I love adventure.
I love a challenge.
So that was kind of my motivation toward a career in the military.
Where did you attend college, sir?
I went to the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point.
It's one of the five federal academies, probably the least well-known, but nonetheless a federal academy.
What was your reason for choosing this particular school, sir?
Well, I had an appointment to the Naval Academy.
I got an appointment to the Merchant Marine Academy from Senator Robinson of Virginia, and my best buddy also got an appointment, and he really talked me into going there.
It's a small school with a regiment of about 1,000 cadets, and
It sounded interesting to me, so I went.
Sir, when did you report for OCS or begin your Marine career?
Well, when I graduated from college, I was commissioned instant in the Navy, in active Naval Reserve.
I sailed the merchant Marines for one year.
I sailed with the MSCS.
It was called MSTS then, Military Sealift Transportation Service, on the USS General Patch, which was a troop transport going between
New York and Germany.
About that time, the Vietnam War broke out.
I had a twin brother who was a second lieutenant in the Marine Corps then, who was about to go to Vietnam.
So I got real motivated to say, hey, I need to serve my country.
So I resigned from the Air Reserve Commission and came to the Marine Corps through OCS in 1965, March of 1965.
So in essence, you volunteered for duty in Vietnam by going ahead and joining the Marine Corps as an officer?
Well, I joined the Marine Corps at that time.
Vietnam War was just starting to get, the buildup was just starting over there.
I was commissioned in June of 1965 and went to flight school.
I'm a naval aviator, so I went to flight school down in Pensacola, Florida.
I was there.
They had an accelerator program because of the Vietnam War, so I went through flight school in about ten months.
I took part in flight school and joined my first squadron down at Marinko Air Station, New River, North Carolina.
At that time, all my buddies were very anxious to get over to the war, you know, and get a taste of combat.
So it wasn't a matter of volunteering.
If you were the unit that was going to be assigned to go, you were going.
When did you first arrive in Vietnam, sir, and who did you serve with, and in what role?
I first arrived in Vietnam in, let's see, May of 1967.
I joined the Marine Medium Helicopter Squadron 262, which was flying out of the Marine Air Facility Marlowe Mountain, which was on the coastline just east of Da Nang.
I was a squadron pilot primarily.
However, I did work in maintenance and did some work as a flight officer.
mainly flew.
What types of missions did you fly, sir?
We flew assorted missions.

The squadron that I joined was, had entered country as a brand new squadron about six months before I got there, so we had relatively brand new airplanes, and we flew almost just about 2,400 hours a month.
Primarily recon insert extract.
We did a lot of the troop assaults, helicopter-borne assaults.
We did medevac, resupply, you name it.
Basically, we did it.
While you were serving in this role, sir, did you ever have any encounters with the ARVN forces?
Were you ever working directly?
We did a lot of missions with the ARVN where we did helicopter-borne assaults and hauled the ARVN forces into...
into a strike area.
I never during this part of my career had any direct relationship with the Yardmans.
I had a twin brother who was a MACV SOG.
I worked with him on a day-to-day basis.
Based on your knowledge later in your career of the Yardmans, how would you assess them as a fighting force?
Well, the South Vietnamese were
were a developing force.
You could compare them to the South Koreans at the time of the Korean War.
They weren't trained very well.
They weren't equipped very well.
And it was a matter of working with them, giving them the equipment, giving them training.
We did a lot of joint operations to try to develop their capabilities.
But they were far inferior to the US forces and or the Korean forces that were over there.
What did you feel about concerning their desire to fight, their desire to save their country, sir?
Were they lacking?
Were they lazy?

I've read several accounts in the book of Bright and Shining Light where there have been several things said, and also in the book about the lack of desire on the part of the officers to do anything they wanted out of that was to become part of the political hierarchy.
They really had no desire to take it to the end, sir.
Well, I would say that there were some very good Arvin units.
The Arvin Marines were very good.
They were well trained and they fought very violently, but obviously there were some units over there also that weren't as good.
Vietnam, the people were mainly peasants.
You had the hierarchy over there that were schooled and had been more or less trained and developed by the French from Vietnam, who obviously were

maybe uh using the war to meet their own political gains but i think the peasants as a whole were supportive of the war as far as the you know maintaining their freedoms and freedom and you might say a state of democracy however
my impression that they were basic peasants, they were mainly farmers, and they just wanted to be left alone.
And they were caught up into a humongous war, in which they could win.
They could not win.
And what I mean by that is, if the American forces occupied the territory and protected them, they were on the side of the American forces.
But if we left the area, and the VVF-Con came in, or the NVA units came in, well, then they were loyal to the VVF-Con, where it was in power, where they were loyal to kind of
You understand what I'm saying?
Yes, sir.
Prior to arriving in Vietnam, finding out you were assigned to Vietnam, what expectations or feelings or emotions did you have concerning that assignment, sir?
Well, I think every young man wonders what combat's about.
I know I'm from a Marine family, and I just developed buddies I went to high school with,
The Marine Corps were officers in the Marine Corps, and we're going over to Vietnam to fight.
I think knowing that it's kind of an unknown.
You're kind of untested.
You never know how someone's going to respond in combat.
But I found when I got over there that it's doing a job.
You do what you're trained to do, and you get served.
At times you're scared.
Sometimes adrenaline's pumping.
But you have a mission, and you have a goal, and you try to achieve it.
What else was the question there?
Which feelings, expectations, or emotions did you have prior to going to the military?
Yeah, I think that in the 67, 68 time frame, I think most of the young men that went over to Vietnam thought we were going over there for a good cause.
The cause was to stop the communism in South Vietnam.
We felt we were invited by the South Vietnamese government
That our government committed the military forces and our government was behind us.
To understand that the military is really a war is, let me put it this way, war is an instrument of policy.
The military is an instrument of policy.
So when the politicians and the nation agree to commit forces, then the military doesn't question why we go.
How did these feelings or emotions change as your time in the country wore on, sir?
From President Johnson to President Nixon, the Vietnamization plan, things like that, sir.
How did those affect your feelings, or did your feelings change as far as the outcome of the war, sir?
as far as why you personally were there, sir?
Well, I was in Penford for almost two years, over two years.
My first tour, I flew helicopters.
I fought in the Battle of Quezon and the Battle of Waste City.
I had the squadron I was in during the siege of Quezon lost 30 aircraft and just about 10 air crews.
I was shot myself.
My second tour, I flew OB-10s as a light attack, visual reconnaissance, forward air control airborne, controlled over 550 flights of fixed-wing aircraft, close air support on enemy targets.
During my two years there, the thing that amazed me was the American's military might, the power of the
We have troops in contact within minutes.
We could have artillery, naval gunfire, close air support overhead, supporting friendly forces.
It was that way the entire time I was there.
I never saw us lose a battle.
Like I say, I was very busy.
Flying over the Thames, I flew six hours a day, seven days a week.
I didn't have a lot of time to be thinking about other things other than doing the mission.
You get up on a six-hour mission where perhaps you have full Gs for...

three hours, flying in an un-air-conditioned cockpit at 120 degrees, firing your own ordnance, controlling other airplanes, talking to troops on the ground in a panic mode, you don't have a lot of time to be thinking about anything but the mission.
So the thing, like I say, I was very proud of the American Fighting Forces over there, and I think we did a good job.
However, it was discouraging from the point is that
We had so many political ties put on us, restrictions, that the way we were going about it, we could never win the war.
We won a lot of individual battles, but never won the war.
All right, sir.
I was just curious as to what kind of news you all received in country from the home front.
Did the news of the protests on the campuses, things like that, get back to you and to other Marines, sir?
And if it did, how did it affect the morale of the American fighting men in country?
Well, in those days, it didn't quite have the perhaps the media blitz they have in modern warfare.
But I think it probably impacted the people more in the military back here in the States than it did in any country.
You know, the only newspaper we got was Stargent Strikes, which was a military paper that was really talked about
troops and people that were actually fighting in combat.

I think the biggest thing I can remember that probably really hurt American military men was in, I believe it was in 69, it may have been the 70s, I believe it was 69 when Jane Fonda went up to Hanoi.
We in the military considered her a traitor to the nation.
That hurt.
But the thing is, when all these demonstrations were going on, and the peace movements, and the campus unrest, I missed most of that because I was in Vietnam.
I read a little bit about it in the paper, but I wasn't here to actually see it.
So I never really felt the impact of that until I got back and finally realized that I was kind of an outcast because I was a military man.
And that was disappointing.
Sir, what kind of treatment did you receive from the public when you came back to the United States following your retreat?
Well, that was almost kind of like a non-treatment.
Of course, a lot of people would cuss at you and call you warmongers.
A lot of things were happening during that time.
We were burning recruit centers and buildings and a lot of demonstrations outside military facilities.
Because I came in the military, and the military is a very honorable profession.
It's a lot like being a doctor, you know, saying equivalency, and it's a very honorable profession.
And for the average military man, we didn't see that we were doing anything wrong.
We were doing, again, the military is an instrument of policy.
War is an instrument of policy.
The politicians who were voted by the American people send the military in the action.
The military, we're not political.
We do what we're told to do to protect the Americans' interests.
So for us, it was a big disappointment.
Sir, obviously when you entered the conflict, you entered it feeling that the Americans would more than likely win the war and end the communist aggression.
If at any point, when did you change your mind, considering the fact that we may not win the war, and why did you change your mind, sir?
Well, I still to this day believe we could have won the war if it was fought correctly.
You've got to understand, in Vietnam, we fought when the enemy wanted to fight us.
The enemy, at any time, could run across the border in the Laos, Cambodia, North Vietnam, and we couldn't chase them.
We were restricted to stay in South Vietnam.
So they would come across at a given time and fight.
They would usually lose that battle, go back across the border, retrain, resupply, regroup, and wait until the time was right to defeat an enemy.
You've got to go at a center of gravity, and that is the enemy.
You've got to go where the enemy is, and you've got to defeat them.
If the enemy's in North Vietnam, you're going to North Vietnam.
If it's in Laos, you go to Laos.
You try to isolate the enemy.
Instead, we were constricted into a boundary where the enemy was given sanctuary, where they could go where we couldn't touch them, and we'd have to wait for them to come back in and fight.
We were micromanaged at the highest level, i.e., the President of the United States,
There were a lot of things there that really tied our hands.
I've made time to go on a strike into a village and be shot at and having Marines killed, but you weren't allowed to fire in that village until you got parents from Saigon to fire.
I mean, it was just a different type of war.
Please understand that the political situation then was such that I think Congress knew what had to be done, but they were so afraid that if we went into North Vietnam with troops,
that the Chinese and the Russians may have come into the war, that they were afraid to do that.
So they were trying to keep it strictly, but you know, you can't win a defensive war.
We were on the defense down here.
The only time we could take the offense is when the enemy took the offense and attacked us.
And then once we beat them, they ran across the border.
We did bomb across the border, but we couldn't do anything.
Again, what was the CG of the Americans in the Vietnam's eyes?
What they saw was that they had time on their side.
They saw the will of the American people as their center of gravity.
I think they saw that if they waited long enough, the American people would not stand for our forces to be there, and eventually we would pull out.
And they were right.
Sir, do you believe that's the whole reason behind the 10th incident?
Because many military analysts have said that the Viet Cong were crazy for launching that offensive.
They knew they couldn't win it.
Well, the Tet Offensive, I think they really thought they could.
If you look at, if you study the Battle of Khe Sanh, for example, they saw Khe Sanh as another din-din food.
If you look where Khe Sanh was located, it was located up on the northwest corner of Vietnam.
It was about six miles from Laos.
It was about ten miles south of the DMZ.
It was in a valley.
It was surrounded by mountains.
It set to the west, which were rolling hills that went into Laos.
That offensive normally starts their new year in January, and it's right during the monsoon season.
So they say, hey, we bring in 30,000, 40,000 troops.
We surround Quezon.
The monsoons are there.
If they can't get the air support, we're going to beat them.
Quezon only had the 26 Marines up there.
They had about 6,000 to 7,000 Marines, and they were surrounded by 30,000 to 40,000 NVA troops.
Now, these were hardline NVA soldiers, not yet conned.
They had all kinds of equipment up there.
They had anti-aircraft guns.
They had artillery.
They had rockets.
They had mortars.
I was there the night the siege started.
I was flying medevac out of Quezon on the surrounding hills.
And I recall it was January 21, 1968.
We took 1,600 rounds of artillery at that base that night.
We hit the ammo dump.
The ammo dump took off for 48 hours.
It was just a massive, massive attack.
But they really felt if they could win that battle, the Battle of Quezon, the siege, that they would be victorious.
And the Americans, just like the Dinh Binh Phu when they beat the French, and the French decided it was time to leave Vietnam, they'd had enough.
Well, Lyndon Johnson said we weren't going to lose.
case on them, and we didn't.
It was a Herculean effort that I think air support saved the day.
They had B-52 bombers bombing every 90 minutes.
And that's what they call an arc light.
You know an arc light here?
Yes, sir.

They did have sometimes 12 to 20 aircraft come over, and each B-52 carries 125 500-pound bombs, and they had 20 of those times 125 coming down, and when they hit the ground, they looked like an arc of light, massive.
They had air coverage 24 hours a day.
Even though the weather was bad, they did their radar bombing using TTQ-10 radars with A6s.
And a flight of A6s carries 52 500-pound bombs.
And this was going on 24 hours a day around the compound of Quezon.
The fact is, I make a comparison.
Before the siege started up there, it was a beautiful country site up there.
I mean, it was luscious green jungles.
They had tigers, monkeys, beautiful mountains.
jungle canopy.
In fact, right on the south end of the runway there, Cason, is a waterfall that dropped down about 200 feet into the Belong Valley.
Just a beautiful setting.
When that siege was over, it looked like the moon.
There wasn't anything green, just craters for as far as you could look.
It was massive.
So the Marines officially, I think the record said they lost 204.
I think we lost about 800, according to the logs of the
the time they stationed up there.
They say the NVA lost about 10,000, but they don't know.
With a massive bombing, they have lost major units.
It was massive.
That was a big loss to the South.
That was a big loss, I mean, to North Vietnam.
And I think they really thought that ahead of 68, they were going to win the war.
Then they realized they probably weren't, and it became a matter of a waiting game.
Again, you know, strike, retreat, strike, retreat.
just keep killing off American troops, people back here saying, hey, you know, peace movements, get us out of there.
You know, we've lost 50,000.
We don't lose any more.
What's the cause?
You know, the government down in South Vietnam is corrupt.
You know, it's time to get out.
So in some regards, you know, I look at the way we're fighting the war, we're going to win it.
They had to make some major policy changes for us to win the war.
So looking at it from that perspective, they're probably smart with that.
from a fighting man that won many battles that I hate to say we lost.
I understand.

Sir, almost 20 years after the fall of Saigon, what, if anything, had you been one of the politicians and, well, been the President of the United States for that matter, would you have done differently in Vietnam?
Well, there are a lot of lessons learned.
I think if you study history and...
The American people, up until the Korean conflict, had only fought unlimited wars.
You know what an unlimited war is.
Unconditional surrender.
You kick ass, you take names, you destroy the enemy, and you turn over the government.
But the Cree is the first time this nation ever fought a limited war, and they didn't like it.
They weren't used to it.
They're not used to fighting for limited objectives.
I think Vietnam was the same way, and we didn't know how to fight limited wars.
But if you look at, I think George Bush must have had a checklist
for Desert Storm to make sure that everything that happened in Vietnam did not happen in Desert Storm.
Let me tell you what I mean.
Number one, he declared war.
He got the will of the American people.
He got the consensus of Congress.
He mobilized the reserves.
Once you mobilize the reserves, you're mobilizing the citizen soldiers that are getting more and more involved into the war.
He had a firm political objective.
You know what his objective was?
It was to kick Kuwaitis
correction, the Iraqis out of Kuwait.
That was the objective.
What was the objective of the Vietnam War?
No one really knew.
Campaign for communism, what's that mean?
They knew where the defined boundaries were.
It wasn't micromanaged by the president.
They gave the total control of the war to military commander Schwarzkopf.
There's some other things that I can't think of right now, but, I mean, it was done exactly the way it should have been done.
And I think if we'd done that same thing in Vietnam, number one, we may not have gone in the first place.
But if we did go, we could have won it.
Sir, what kind of strategy would you have implemented in Vietnam had you been in charge of all the troops in the country, i.e., the strategic handling program?
No, to me, what I would have done is gone and defeated the North Vietnamese Army.
That's what you had to do.
Vietnam, it was so different than any war we've ever fought in.
You know, you hear, you know, it was a guerrilla war.
You had conventional forces fighting.
But you've got to understand that when we got over there as an American fighting force, the Viet Cong North NVA infrastructure was throughout the South.
They control all the hamlets in the villages, and they did it through terrorist tactics.
I mean, very easy.
If you go into a village, you hang up the village chief's wife on a stake and, you know, cut her open, let her guts hang out, and people get the message, you know, those people are in control.
When we came in, it's not like we started in the south tip of Vietnam and just marched all the way north, and everything behind us we owned.
It never happened that way.
We moved in, we put forces in the north, some in the central, some in the south,
Everywhere we physically occupied, we controlled.
But all the area around where we physically occupied, the D.C. and the NBA controlled.
And even if we would have started to south and moved north, all they would have done is pushed into Cambodia and Laos, and then as soon as we got further north, they'd come in behind us in the south.
So you can't win a war like that.
You've got to be able to isolate the enemy.
We never isolated the enemy.
We couldn't.
We had the boundaries put on us.
They had no boundaries.
So what you had to do is find where the majority of the NVA forces were.
They're in North Vietnam.
You go up there.
You can do your blockade.
You can do a big air assault like we did up at Iraq where you're going to knock out their bases, their supply dumps, their SAM sites, anything that's strategic.
But then you've got to go defeat the army.
You've got to locate the army.
You've got to beat them.
That's how you win wars.
And that's what I would have done.
Now, you say, well, that's easy to say, Barbette.
When you were sent to the White House, you didn't understand the other pressures.
Well, I understand the other pressures.
I understand the concern about Russia or the Chinese coming into the war.
But you've got to ask yourself, do you want to win the war or not?
If you want to win the war, you've got to take that risk.
If you didn't want to win the war, then we couldn't have been over there.
So you don't think that Fletchmore would have gotten additional troops to call for in 1968?
No.
That wouldn't have made any difference?
Wouldn't have made any difference.
it would not have made any difference.
Because, again, the troops still, you couldn't fight the enemy.
The enemy was in Laos, Cambodia, and North Vietnam.
They only came across the border when they wanted to inflict injury on you, and then they ran.
So you think we would have lifted the restrictions on operations in Cambodia, Laos, and North Vietnam?
change the outcomes here?
They would have made a big difference.
They would have made a big difference.
I even know after the Tet Offensive of 68, we were catching prisoners up in the Khe Sanh area.
There were kids that were 14 years old.
The NDA soldiers were 14 years old.
Their morale was at low at that point.
They really lost.
They really thought they were going to come down into South Vietnam and win.
They lost big time.
Without the air power, there's no way they could defeat American forces.
No way whatsoever.
They were tenacious fighters.
They could live in a hole, in a tunnel, on a bag of rice for one week.
Tough little guys.
I like the Iranians.
They didn't quit.
They were tough little fighters.
And I respect them as a fighting force, but they couldn't beat us.
But we couldn't beat them either unless we could go fight their army.
We couldn't just wait for them to come to us and then let them run away.
That's what I'm saying.
The defeat, if you
If you look at the...
I'll make a parallel here to Desert Storm.
We really fought a war of attrition.
We fought a war of attrition.
Basically, the troops that are around Kuwait, we cut off all their lines of communications, all their supply lines.
They couldn't get reinforced.
They couldn't even communicate with their headquarters.
Then we went up there and bombed all their strategic points, all their airfields, all their bases, all their supply lines.
you know, all the headquarters and communication sites.
So they were isolated down there.
Then the right time came, and we surrounded them, and then we went in and went in for their army and beat them.
We had to defeat their army.
That was just the opposite.
Here in Vietnam, take the battery.
Here you've got South Vietnam here.
Here's our forces in South Vietnam, but the enemy isn't in South Vietnam.
They have, yeah, some
Forces, small units of forces there, they're going to keep harassing us and firing mortars and rockets.
But their main army is in Cambodia, Laos, and North Vietnam.
They plan a major offensive.
They come across the border.
They attack you.
You fight.
You win.
They retreat across the border.
And you can't chase them.
You just stop.
Then they sit there.
They regroup.
They retrain.
They resupply.
And when the timing's right, they come across again.

In the meantime, they're inflicting harassment actions all the time through artillery or having two or three guys sneak in through a base camp area and fire a couple of mortars or a 122-round rocket or whatever the case might be.
So you can see there's no way we could win unless they just decided to give up because they had enough.
And those people, you've got to understand the Asian mind.
Time is on their side.
Sir, historians debate whether or not we won or lost the war.
From your perspective, sir, I'd like to hear your thoughts on that question.
My thoughts are, and again I...
